definition: **noun / slang.** A rare cutting-lathe mishap where the groove briefly swerves sideways forming a distinctive "hook" or "J" shape, causing an audible click, pop, or stylus mistrack during playback. This defect typically occurs during the lacquer cutting process when the lathe's cutting head experiences a momentary mechanical disturbance—vibration from external sources, a sudden feedback spike, or microscopic debris interfering with the cutting stylus. The resulting hook-shaped deviation disrupts the groove's continuous spiral, forcing the stylus to jump laterally before resuming normal tracking. J-cuts are most commonly found on test pressings and early lacquer transfers, rarely making it to production runs due to quality control. Collectors sometimes encounter them on small-run independent releases or bootlegs cut on poorly maintained equipment. Unlike intentional locked grooves, J-cuts are always unintentional defects that diminish playback quality and, in severe cases, can damage stylus cantilevers on high-compliance cartridges.
etymology: Named for the visual resemblance to the letter "J" when the groove deviation is viewed under magnification; term emerged among cutting engineers and audiophile collectors in the 1970s.
